latest news.eng_title: California Aims to Regulate AI, but Big Tech Companies Resist
latest news.summary: The state of California is on the verge of passing a law that regulates artificial intelligence, but it has generated discontent among big tech companies and AI startups, with the exception of Elon Musk. The proposed law aims to reduce the potential risks of AI and requires big tech companies to test their models and publicly disclose their security protocols. Senator Scott Wiener, who drafted the proposal, said, 'Innovation and security can go hand in hand, and California is paving the way.' However, big tech companies such as OpenAI, Google, and Meta have opposed the law, arguing that it targets developers rather than those who misuse AI systems. OpenAI has stated that it prefers national regulations over a patchwork of state laws. In contrast, Elon Musk has expressed support for the proposal, calling it a 'difficult choice.' The law is also supported by Anthropic, an AI startup backed by Amazon and Google.
latest news.title: La California studia come regolare l'AI. E le big tech si dividono

latest news.eng_title: AI Firms' ‘Free Lunch' Runs Out Amid Wave of Lawsuits
latest news.summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) companies are facing a wave of copyright lawsuits and allegations of aggressively scraping data from the internet. According to a report by the Financial Times, AI firms have reached the 'data frontier,' where they must purchase or produce data instead of scraping it. Alex Ratner, co-founder of Snorkel AI, said, 'There's no more free lunch. You can't scrape a web-scale dataset any more. You have to go and purchase it or produce it. That's the frontier we're at now.' Anthropic was recently sued by authors who accused the company of stealing copyrighted books, and OpenAI is facing a lawsuit from The New York Times for copyright infringement. Experts say that content scraping undermines the efforts of content creators and can produce derivative content that outranks the original in search results, depriving the creator of revenue.
latest news.title: AI Firms' ‘Free Lunch' Runs Out Amid Wave of Lawsuits

latest news.eng_title: Amazon Partners with Anthropic to Revamp Alexa with Advanced AI
latest news.summary: Amazon is preparing a significant update to its voice assistant Alexa, set to launch in October 2024, just before the US holiday season. The new version of Alexa will primarily use the advanced artificial intelligence (AI) models developed by Anthropic, known as Claude, instead of relying on its own internal AI technology. According to sources, the Claude models have shown to be faster and more accurate, offering more complete and timely responses (MacRumors). Amazon invested $4 billion in Anthropic in September 2023, gaining access to the advanced capabilities of the Anthropic models, particularly the Claude 3, which has demonstrated human-like intelligence in areas such as reasoning, mathematics, and programming. The new Alexa will offer two versions: a free 'Classic' version and a paid 'Remarkable' version, which will cost between $5 and $10 per month. The 'Remarkable' version will use advanced generative AI to handle complex queries, maintain conversations based on previous questions and answers, and perform tasks such as ordering food or writing emails with a single command. Amazon aims to increase Alexa's profitability and stay competitive in the voice assistant market, where other tech giants like Microsoft and Apple have established partnerships with companies like OpenAI. The new version of Alexa is expected to generate at least $600 million in annual sales if 10% of its 100 million active users opt for the paid version.
latest news.title: Amazon se asocia con Anthropic para revitalizar Alexa con IA avanzada

latest news.eng_title: California's AI Safety Bill Sparks Controversy in Silicon Valley
latest news.summary: California's AI Safety Bill, SB 1047, has sparked controversy in Silicon Valley. The bill aims to lower the risks of using advanced AI models by requiring strict safety procedures, such as an 'emergency stop' button and yearly checks by a third party. Supporters, including State Senator Scott Wiener and AI experts Geoffrey Hinton and Yoshua Bengio, argue that the bill is necessary to prevent potential misuse of AI. However, opponents, including venture capital firms and tech giants like Meta and Google, worry that the bill's standards are not logical and could hurt the AI ecosystem. Changes were made to the bill, including replacing possible criminal penalties with civil ones, but it remains controversial. Governor Gavin Newsom has until the end of September to sign or veto the bill, which could set a big example for AI regulation in the US.
latest news.title: California's AI Safety Bill Sparks Controversy in Silicon Valley

latest news.eng_title: OpenAI's Secret Project 'Strawberry' to Revolutionize ChatGPT
latest news.summary: OpenAI is expected to launch the fifth generation of ChatGPT, codenamed 'Strawberry', which will have improved capabilities, especially in mathematics and programming. According to sources, the new model will be able to solve mathematical problems better than previous AI models. ChatGPT has faced criticism for its performance in mathematics, with many users reporting errors in solving simple problems. Experts attribute these errors to the lack of mathematical information in the data used to train the model. The new model is also expected to have a wider range of advanced cognitive abilities, including solving complex puzzles like the 'Connections' game published by The New York Times. The project has been shrouded in secrecy, but it is believed to have been presented to US national security officials, which is consistent with OpenAI's statement that it will inform the US government about its upcoming AI models before their release. The project is expected to be revealed by September or October, and it may be integrated into the fifth version of ChatGPT or used to improve the quality of the training data for the next AI model, aiming to reduce the 'hallucinations' or errors that are often reported. As reported by 'theinformation', a source close to the project said, 'It will be a major upgrade, and it will be able to solve math problems better than any previous model.'
latest news.title: OpenAI تقترب من إطلاق الجيل الخامس من ChatGPT

latest news.eng_title: California AI Bill Passes Senate, Divides Tech Industry

Law: Safe and Secure Innovation for Frontier Artificial Intelligence Models Act

latest news.summary: A new California artificial intelligence bill, the Safe and Secure Innovation for Frontier Artificial Intelligence Models Act (SB 1047), has passed the California Senate with a 29-9 vote. The bill requires AI firms to implement safety protocols, including an 'emergency stop' button for AI models. Elon Musk expressed support for the bill, citing the 'potential risk' of AI. However, not all tech figures agree, with OpenAI's Jason Kwon and Masa's Calanthia Mei criticizing the legislation. Mei warned that premature regulations will drive talent out of California and America, while Govindji of DecideAI proposed a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO)-controlled killswitch to meet the requirements. The bill's definition of 'covered models' will shift over time, and companies that fail to comply will face civil penalties. OpenAI's Kwon argued that AI legislation should be handled at a federal level, but the bill's impact may be de facto national due to California's concentration of tech and AI firms.
latest news.title: Tuấn Hưng mắc sai lầm

latest news.eng_title: What The California AI 'Killswitch' Bill Means For Decentralized AI

Law: Safe and Secure Innovation for Frontier Artificial Intelligence Models Act
Title: Governor

latest news.summary: A California bill, the Safe and Secure Innovation for Frontier Artificial Intelligence Models Act (SB 1047), has passed the state Senate and is awaiting ratification by Governor Gavin Newsom. The bill aims to regulate AI development, but industry figures are divided on its impact. Elon Musk expressed support for the bill, citing the 'potential risk' of AI, while OpenAI's Jason Kwon and Masa's Calanthia Mei criticized it, arguing that it will drive talent out of California and the US. DecideAI's Raheel Govindji supports the bill, proposing a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO)-controlled killswitch. The bill requires AI models to be able to 'promptly enact a full shutdown,' but fails to define 'promptly.' Govindji believes a DAO model will satisfy this requirement. Anthropic has also publicly supported the bill, citing the importance of averting catastrophic misuse. The bill will only apply to 'covered models,' defined as AI that costs over $100 million to develop or uses a quantity of computing power greater than 10^26 integer or floating-point operation.
latest news.title: What The California AI 'Killswitch' Bill Means For Decentralized AI

latest news.eng_title: OpenAI Faces Growing Competition from Startups with More Efficient AI Models
latest news.summary: The Wall Street Journal warns of increasing competition from startups that offer AI services at lower prices and develop their own models that better handle specialized tasks. Meta Platforms, led by Mark Zuckerberg, supports startups developing open-source AI, considering it a more democratic and accessible option. Google has also released an open-source AI model. Unlike OpenAI, which charges for access to its advanced models, startups with open-source AI offer their solutions for free. Experts predict that users will eventually use various AI models from both closed and open sources. Open-source AI is rapidly catching up in terms of efficiency with leading players in the field, particularly in everyday business applications requiring high performance and low costs. Meta reported that its Llama model has been downloaded over 350 million times, while OpenAI claims that ChatGPT has 200 million active users per week. Startups like Adaptive ML use open-source AI to create small, customizable models for businesses. These models are easier to integrate and cheaper to maintain, attracting the attention of large corporations. The growing competition, shift to open-source AI, and increasing efficiency of specialized models pose a significant challenge to OpenAI's dominance in the AI market. The future of AI is likely to be characterized by a diversity of models and more accessible solutions provided by both closed and open sources, as said, 'It is a more democratic and accessible option.'
latest news.title: Появились конкуренты OpenAI с более выгодными и эффективными ИИ-моделями

latest news.eng_title: Meta leads open-source AI boom, Llama downloads surge 10x year-over-year
latest news.summary: Meta has reported a significant surge in the adoption of its open-source Llama models, with downloads approaching 350 million on Hugging Face, a ten-fold increase from last year. The company claims that large enterprises such as Zoom, Spotify, and Goldman Sachs are using the models for various internal and external use cases. This marks a major milestone for open-source AI, which is now rivaling closed-source models in terms of performance and adoption. As Yann LeCun noted, 'Universities, researchers, and engineers are improving Llama and building new products and services.' This success has raised questions about OpenAI's lead in the generative AI space, which has been criticized for failing to deliver frontier AI products beyond announcements. Meta's open-source play appears to be paying off, with Llama becoming the dominant platform in the AI ecosystem.
latest news.title: Meta leads open-source AI boom, Llama downloads surge 10x year-over-year

news knowledge.eng_title: Is open source AI possible, let alone the future? Find out at TechCrunch Disrupt 2024
news knowledge.summary: At TechCrunch Disrupt 2024, Hugging Face's Irene Solaiman and AI2's Ali Farhadi will discuss the possibility of open source AI, a concept that some believe can break the proprietary software cycle that AI has fallen into. Solaiman, Hugging Face's head of global policy, and Farhadi, a leader at AI2, are proponents of openness and transparency in AI, but acknowledge the challenges of making open source AI a reality due to the resource requirements of AI models. The panel discussion will take place at Disrupt 2024 in San Francisco from October 28-30. 'It's certain to be an extremely interesting conversation,' said the moderator. 'What will it take to change the status quo and make open source AI a reality?'
news knowledge.title: Is open source AI possible, let alone the future? Find out at TechCrunch Disrupt 2024

news knowledge.eng_title: Hugging Face and AI2 to join the AI Stage at Disrupt 2024
news knowledge.summary: Hugging Face's Irene Solaiman and AI2's Ali Farhadi will discuss the challenges of open source AI on a panel at TechCrunch Disrupt 2024. They will explore the possibilities and challenges of defining, creating, and providing access to open AI systems, despite the resource requirements of AI models making open source alternatives difficult. Solaiman, Hugging Face's head of global policy, and Farhadi, a proponent of openness and transparency, acknowledge the structural barriers facing the embodiment of these principles in AI. 'It's certain to be an extremely interesting conversation,' according to the TechCrunch article. The panel will take place at Disrupt 2024 in San Francisco from October 28-30.
news knowledge.title: Hugging Face and AI2 to join the AI Stage at Disrupt 2024

news knowledge.eng_title: Mark Zuckerberg Advocates for Open Source AI as Industry Standard
news knowledge.summary: Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Meta, has advocated for open-source AI as the future of technology development. He believes that open-source AI models will outpace closed systems by offering greater flexibility, security, and cost efficiency. Zuckerberg highlighted releasing Llama 3.1, a frontier-level open-source AI model, as a significant step towards making open source the industry standard. He argues that open-source AI will be safer, more accessible, and more beneficial in the long term, as it democratizes access to AI technology, prevents power from being concentrated in a few companies, and enhances global security. Zuckerberg's vision is for open-source AI to become the foundation of future technological and economic advancements.
news knowledge.title: Mark Zuckerberg Advocates for Open Source AI as Industry Standard

news knowledge.eng_title: Generative AI Digest: The debate over open-source vs. closed-source models
news knowledge.summary: The past month has seen a surge in new large language models from various companies, including OpenAI, Mistral AI, Google, Runway AI, and Meta. Meta's Llama 3.1, a 405 billion-parameter open-source model, has drawn significant attention for its performance comparable to leading closed-source models. However, none of these models are truly open-source, as they require separate licenses for commercial use. The debate between open-source and closed-source models has been influenced by the dominance of leading frontier models, but the release of Llama 3.1 has narrowed the gap, providing organizations with more control over their models. Other notable product and funding announcements include OpenAI's acquisition of Multi Software, Cohere's $500 million series D funding, and Harvey's $100 million funding for its AI-powered legal assistant platform.
news knowledge.title: Generative AI Digest: The debate over open-source vs. closed-source models

news knowledge.eng_title: Meta Just launched the Largest ‘Open' AI Model in History. Here's Why It Matters.
news knowledge.summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, has released the largest 'open' AI model in history, Llama 3.1 405B, which is considered a frontier-level open-source AI model. This move is significant as it allows for community collaboration, scrutiny, and identification of potential biases and vulnerabilities. However, open-source AI also creates new risks and ethical concerns, such as low quality control and the potential for malicious use. Meta's move is seen as a step towards democratizing AI and ensuring that it serves the greater good. The article highlights the importance of three key pillars for achieving this goal: governance, accessibility, and openness. It also raises questions about how to balance protecting intellectual property and fostering innovation through open-source AI, and how to minimize ethical concerns and safeguard against potential misuse.
news knowledge.title: Meta Just launched the Largest ‘Open' AI Model in History. Here's Why It Matters.

news knowledge.eng_title: Meta Just Launched The Largest 'Open' AI Model In History. Heres Why It Matters
news knowledge.summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, has released the largest 'open' AI model in history, Llama 3.1 405B. This model is considered a 'frontier-level open-source AI model' by Meta's founder and CEO, Mark Zuckerberg. The release of this model is seen as a step towards making AI technology more accessible and transparent. However, some concerns remain about the potential risks and ethical implications of open-source AI, including the lack of quality control and the potential for misuse. Despite these concerns, Meta's move is seen as a positive step towards democratizing AI and ensuring that it serves the greater good.
news knowledge.title: Meta Just Launched The Largest 'Open' AI Model In History. Heres Why It Matters

news knowledge.eng_title: Meta Platforms Just Released an Artificial Intelligence (AI) Game-Changer -- And It Could Be Dangerous | The Motley Fool
news knowledge.summary: Meta has released its Llama 3.1 model, a frontier AI model with 405 billion parameters, which outperforms other models on many parameters. The model is open-source, allowing developers to modify and improve it. Mark Zuckerberg believes this will make Meta the world's most-used AI assistant by the end of the year, surpassing OpenAI. However, there are risks to open-source AI, including privacy and security concerns, which may lead to government scrutiny and regulation. Zuckerberg argues that these risks are outweighed by the benefits of open innovation, but the approach may still face challenges.
news knowledge.title: Meta Platforms Just Released an Artificial Intelligence (AI) Game-Changer -- And It Could Be Dangerous | The Motley Fool

news knowledge.eng_title: AI is approaching an open-source inflection point
news knowledge.summary: Meta's open-source Llama models have reached an important threshold, with the latest model achieving 'frontier-level' status, comparable to the most powerful AI from companies like OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic. According to Mark Zuckerberg, future Llama models will surpass others to become the world's most advanced from 2025.
news knowledge.title: AI is approaching an open-source inflection point

news knowledge.eng_title: Mark Zuckerberg calls for open-source AI as Meta releases Llama 3.1
news knowledge.summary: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg has called for open-source artificial intelligence, stating that it will become the industry standard. He believes that AI will follow a similar path to open-source software, with closed models initially leading but open-source eventually catching up. The company has released Llama 3.1, a 'frontier-level open-source AI model' that can converse in multiple languages, write higher-quality code, and solve complex math problems. Zuckerberg expects future Llama models to become the most advanced in the industry, and believes that open-source AI will provide benefits such as customization, independence from closed vendors, data protection, and cost-efficiency. He also argues that open-source AI can be safer due to transparency and wider scrutiny, and that it will be strategically advantageous for the United States and its allies. Zuckerberg concludes that open-source AI will ensure that more people have access to AI benefits, power isn't concentrated in a few companies, and the technology can be deployed more evenly and safely.
news knowledge.title: Mark Zuckerberg calls for open-source AI as Meta releases Llama 3.1

news knowledge.eng_title: Meta unveils latest artificial intelligence models as it plans open source future
news knowledge.summary: Meta has unveiled the latest version of its artificial intelligence models, including Llama 3.1 405B, which will be the first 'frontier-level' open source AI model. The company will also release upgraded Llama 3.1 70B and 8B models. According to Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg, this move marks a significant step forward in the development of AI technology.
news knowledge.title: Meta unveils latest artificial intelligence models as it plans open source future
